Award.AwardTitle: Early Career: Instrument and Technician Support for the Isotopic Analysis of Individual Organic Compounds in the Earth System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant from the Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities program will support the purchase of a peripheral device to be coupled to existing instrumentation shared by Earth science researchers at the University of South Carolina. The instrumentation will provide new analytical capabilities allowing the characterization of isotopic composition of specific organic compounds, which can then be used to better understand processes such as microbial physiology, global biogeochemical cycles and ancient climates. The availability of this instrumentation will provide researchers to enhance their ongoing research, and also provide essential hands-on training to students. The instrumentation will be used as an educational tool to expand on ?textbook? knowledge presented in undergraduate studies, and will be used in a NSF-sponsored Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program.

Specifically, the researchers will acquire a gas chromatograph (GC) peripheral for the operation of a gas-chromatograph-combustion-isotope ratio mass spectrometer (GC-c-IRMS). The integration of a GC front-end peripheral to an existing IRMS instrument will allow the isolation of specific compounds for individual isotopic analysis, which are otherwise masked by ?bulk? analysis of organic matter. The combined instrumentation will advance research in quantifying the amount of bacterially-produced refractory organic matter in the ocean, identifying the activities of belowground microbial communities, and investigating microbial processes in Arctic permafrost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded peripheral instrumentation to support the operation of a new gas chromatograph-combustion-isotope ratio mass spectrometer (GC-c-IRMS). Specifically, a Thermo Scientific GC IsoLink IITM was purchased and installed in November, 2014, and a Gerstel CIS 6 inlet was installed in May, 2015.  This instrumentation was to be used to address the immediate research needs of the co-PIs and collaborators, foster interdisciplinary research outside the department, and enhance graduate and undergraduate education and training.

 Since installation, samples from multiple different research projects have been analyzed. Three of these projects were carried out by undergraduate students, with two generating enough data for the results to be presented at University of South Carolina Undergraduate Research Symposium. In all cases, these students prepared the samples, operated the instrument, and analyzed the data themselves. They learned how to assess the quality of the data and how to process it appropriately.

 One of the undergraduate research projects was to analyze a suite of sediment trap samples spanning 20 years that USC faculty member collaborator had previously collected. The isotopes of the examined compounds are used as proxies for paleoprecipitation, and the results provided constraints on the time between their production and their delivery to the ocean. A second project provided much needed guidance on how to best prevent contamination during store samples for an upcoming field campaign.

The instrument was also used to train graduate students enrolled in “GEOL 715: Stable Isotope Geochemistry,” on the operation of an isotope ratio mass spectrometer in general and a GC-c-IRMS in particular. They learned to prepare samples for the analysis of the 13C of dissolved inorganic carbon, operate the instrument, and process the data. In teaching evaluations, this hands on training was specifically mentioned as an informative and fun exercise.

The instrument has already been extremely effective in generating collaborations inside and outside the department. In addition to ongoing and upcoming projects with other USC faculty, the PIs have also been in contact with multiple external users initiating collaborations to use the instrument.
